ygData.subject: Re: Evolving Soft Robots with CPPNs (New Paper & Video)

Hi Jeff,

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:

> I'=
m of course not opposed to quantitative tests. I'm actually a big fan of th=
em if they are informative. Also, if someone does make a quantitative claim=
 (e.g. performance is higher with algorithm X than Y), then I insist on a p=
-value as a reviewer. Statistics and quantification are important scientifi=
c tools, and in most cases should be present.

p-values are utterly uninfor=
mative (http://ecodevoevo.blogspot.com/2013/05/lets-abandon-significance-te=
sts.html?spref=3Dtw&m=3D1). Ask for effect size instead. :-)
